docs.lead_paragraph: As the snow melts and tiny hard-shelled wood ticks crawl out of the ground and onto bushes and grass where they wait to be swept away by a warm body, state and federal health officials here have begun a study to determine whether Montana is the home of a new type of tick-borne disease similar to Lyme disease. If that is the case, it could join what may be another new tick-borne disease, or perhaps the same one, that has surfaced in Texas and Missouri. Both cause health problems similar to Lyme disease, but not as severe, and both are treatable with antibiotics.

headline.main: Montana Lab Tries to Identify Tick-Borne Disease

docs.abstract: Montana, only state to have never had confirmed case of Lyme disease, seeks answers to tick borne disease similar to Lyme, but less severe; 5 to 10 cases per year of unidentified illness occur in Montana; State epidemiologist Dr Todd Damrow poses several theories about disease, including idea that it might be an adaptation of Lyme disease transfered to wood tick; similar unidentified infectious agents have shown up in Lone Star ticks in Texas and dog ticks in Missouri; photo; map (M)
docs.snippet: As the snow melts and tiny hard-shelled wood ticks crawl out of the ground and onto bushes and grass where they wait to be swept away by a warm body, state and federal health officials here have begun a study to determine whether Montana is the home...

docs.lead_paragraph: Black women die of breast cancer at higher rates than white women with comparable tumors, but the gap disappears among women old enough to qualify for Medicare, according to a study released yesterday. The study's authors suggested that the findings indicated that access to treatment rather than differences in biology probably played a bigger role in the higher death rate for black women than previous research had found. The study also found that later-stage breast cancer was more likely to be diagnosed in black women of all ages, leading the researchers to call for greater efforts to increase screening and follow-up. For the study, which will be published in the June issue of the journal Cancer, the researchers analyzed data collected on more than 110,000 breast cancer cases in 11 states and cities over seven years.
docs.abstract: National Cancer Institute researcher Dr Kenneth C Chu publishes study in journal Cancer that finds disparity in breast cancer death rate between white women and black women may be attributable to health care availability; gap in recovery rate disappeared in women over 65, presumably because they qualify for medicare (S)
docs.snippet: Black women die of breast cancer at higher rates than white women with comparable tumors, but the gap disappears among women old enough to qualify for Medicare, according to a study released yesterday.   The study's authors suggested that the...

docs.lead_paragraph: For smokers trying to quit, a day can feel a lot longer than 24 hours, and a new study shows that in fact a smoker's sense of time is distorted by going without nicotine. The study, published in the journal Psychopharmacology Bulletin, found that smokers allowed access to tobacco and nonsmokers were equally accurate in estimating a 45-second interval, calculating it on average at 52 seconds.
docs.abstract: Dr Laura Cousino Klein, Penn State biobehavioral health assistant professor, publishes study in Psychopharmacology Bulletin that shows smokers, denied cigarettes, display distorted sense of time, which reflects their irritability and impatience without nicotine; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: For smokers trying to quit, a day can feel a lot longer than 24 hours, and a new study shows that in fact a smoker's sense of time is distorted by going without nicotine.    The study, published in the journal Psychopharmacology Bulletin, found that...

docs.lead_paragraph: I met Tom seven days before he died. He was transferred to our hospital with the slim hope that he could receive a combined heart-liver transplant. Donor organs never became available. He died during a desperate resuscitation attempt in our intensive care unit, his unnaturally bronzed 55-year-old body barely visible beneath a tangled mass of tubes, lines and wires.
docs.abstract: Dr David A Shaywitz Cases article discusses how missed diagnosis of hemochromatosis, suprisingly common genetic disorder, contributed to patient's death 20 years later; holds doctors must try to uncover root cause of patient's illness, not just treat symptoms; cartoon (M)
docs.snippet: I met Tom seven days before he died. He was transferred to our hospital with the slim hope that he could receive a combined heart-liver transplant.    Donor organs never became available. He died during a desperate resuscitation attempt in our...

docs.lead_paragraph: With an enemy usually no bigger than the head of a pin, it's no wonder growing numbers of Americans living in Northern states are losing the war against Lyme disease, the most commonly reported illness transmitted by ticks in the United States. Reported cases are at a record high: nearly 18,000 people a year are infected, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which receives reports on only a minority of cases.

headline.main: Fighting Lyme Disease, With a Pinhead as the Enemy

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses ways to prevent tick bites and Lyme disease; Dr Gregory A Poland, Mayo Clinic professor of medicine and infectious disease, notes discrepancies in Lyme disease prevention advice and inherent difficulties in following regimen; due to tiny size of ticks, 70% of people infected with Lyme disease do not even recall being bitten; other advice to ehlp humans and pets avoid tick bites outlined; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: With an enemy usually no bigger than the head of a pin, it's no wonder growing numbers of Americans living in Northern states are losing the war against Lyme disease, the most commonly reported illness transmitted by ticks in the United States.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. José Ribeiro is sequencing the ''spitome'' of the deer tick. This is a little bit like sequencing a genome, except that it has to do with saliva, specifically the saliva of the deer tick, the tiny menace that lives off deer and white-footed mice and likes to give suburban gardeners Lyme disease. What Dr. Ribeiro and other scientists at the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases in Bethesda, Md., are finding is that tick spit is a complex weapon, with an array of components that alleviate pain, keep blood from coagulating and subdue the host's immune system at the site of the bite. ''Tick saliva is amazing,'' said Dr. Fred S. Kantor of the Yale School of Medicine, who is also working on deciphering tick saliva.

headline.main: Looking for a Vaccine to Defang the Lyme Tick

docs.abstract: Transmission of Lyme disease from ticks is substantial problem with more than 16,000 new infections each year; Dr Jose Ribeiro and others at National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases in Bethesda (Maryland) are studying tick saliva as part of effort to develop human vaccine; vaccine in development would bombard tick with unfriendly internal stimulus at moment they bite causing effects of tick bite to be diminished or eliminated; other researchers are working on environmental controls such as pesticides applied to deer or mouse fur that kill ticks; description and anatomy of ticks and their bites are presented; basic method of avoiding bites is discussed; photos, drawings; chart (L)
docs.snippet: Dr. José Ribeiro is sequencing the ''spitome'' of the deer tick. This is a little bit like sequencing a genome, except that it has to do with saliva, specifically the saliva of the deer tick, the tiny menace that lives off deer and white-footed mice...

docs.lead_paragraph: The ticks may not have gotten the message -- they are still out in the woods in full force, biting human flesh at every opportunity -- but many of the people in Lyme disease country and their doctors have decided that the illness is not going to alarm them so much anymore. Gladys Suessle, an early victim in the 2003 season, began her 10-day regimen of antibiotics this month, with every confidence that she would be quickly cured.

headline.main: Some Fears Are Relieved as Lyme Becomes Easier to Manage and Treat

docs.abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports 17,000 Lyme disease infections each year in US, but doctors and patients, becoming more experienced at recognizing and dealing with disease, find Lyme disease easier to treat and easier to manage as fewer cases of late stage illness occur; Annals of Internal Medicine study, led by Dr Gary P Wormser, New York Medical College in Valhalla (NY) infectious diseases chief, finds shorter antibiotic regimens are just as effective as longer cycles showing 85% full recovery rate in two-and-half years; some critics of shortened treatment believe there is still no evidence that infection can be eradicated in 10 days, only symptoms, and keep patients on antibiotics for month or more; theories are given as to why Lyme disease symptoms persist even when infection in gone; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: The mercury in ordinary saltwater fish eaten by pregnant women does not appear to affect their children, according to a study published on Friday in The Lancet. An earlier study of among Inuits in the Faeroe Islands found that children of women with higher mercury levels were more likely to have impaired language or attention skills at age 7.

headline.main: New Look at Fish and Pregnancy

docs.abstract: University of Rochester researcher Dr Gary J Myers leads study published in Lancet that discredits earlier data and shows that mothers who eat fish with standard levels of mercury cause no harm to their unborn children; study tested children in Seychelles, where women eat fish average of 12 times per week, and found children's scores were average on battery of developmental tests (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Better Than Well: American Medicine Meets the American Dream,'' by Dr. Carl Elliott. W. W. Norton & Company, $26.95. The path from Walden Pond to plastic surgery may be hard to discern, and seem completely off the map, until you read ''Better Than Well.'' A philosophical tour of Botox, liposuction and Prozac, among other modern medical enhancements, this book points to their roots in a long and uniquely American quest for personal discovery and transformation.
docs.abstract: Minnesota University professor Carl Elliott book, Better Than Well: American Medicine Meets American Dream, explores medicine's involvement in self-improvement business and reasons behind America's obsession with transformation; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Putting babies to sleep on their backs or sides not only reduces their chance of dying, but cuts down on fevers, sniffles and ear infections, a new study says. Dr. Carl E. Hunt, the study's lead author, said that over the last decade, pediatricians had convinced most of the nation's parents that letting infants sleep face down increased their risk of sudden infant death syndrome, or SIDS.

headline.main: When Babies Sleep Right Side Up

docs.abstract: Dr Carl E Hunt, National Center on Sleep Disorders director, finds infants that sleep on their sides or backs are less likely to suffer ear infections, fevers or stuffy noses; originally given as pediatric recommendation to reduce likelihood of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome, study, published in Archives of Pediatric & Adolescent Medicine, found putting babies on their backs or sides appears to have no downside; cartoon (S)
